abstracts.cdata!:
This Result Profile talks about
            modernizing public water services in Uruguay. Given
            Uruguay’s public utilities like water, electricity and
            telecommunications were monopolies in their respective
            sectors, which has made it difficult to benchmark and
            provide entry points to improve performance. In addition,
            the country’s public water and sanitation utility lagged
            behind other public service providers in terms of
            operational performance and customer service. The
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            worked with Uruguay to modernize its water utility company,
            Obras Sanitarias del Estado (OSE), helping in its
            transformation from an inefficient monopoly into a more
            accountable public utility providing better quality water to
            more Uruguayans than ever before. With the help of IBRD,
            Uruguay’s OSE had slowly evolved from a highly inefficient
            water utility into a solid one over the course of the last
            two decades. As a result of IBRD involvement, Uruguay has
            created a more transparent and accountable water sector.
            OSE, which formerly acted as de facto policymaker and
            regulator in addition to service provider in the water
            sector, has become a part of a wider system that includes an
            autonomous water and electricity regulator, and a separate
            policy-making agency, created in 2006.
